name: Ellis Island
description: Famous immigrant processing station in New York Harbor that plays a role in Michael Corleone's family history.

content.title: Overview
content.body: Ellis Island was the primary immigration station in the United States from 1892 to 1954, through which millions of immigrants passed. In The Godfather Part II, it symbolizes the Corleone family's immigrant roots and the American immigrant experience.

content.title: Appearance
content.body: In the film, Ellis Island is shown with its iconic red brick buildings and a vast reception area where immigrants are inspected and processed. The architecture reflects the grandeur and stern bureaucracy of the era, evoking the challenging journey of many newcomers.

content.title: History
content.body: Historically, Ellis Island served as the gateway for over 12 million immigrants entering the United States. It was known both for hope and hardship, as immigrants faced inspection, quarantine, and possible deportation. This setting establishes the early 20th century context crucial to the Corleone family story.

content.title: Story Significance
content.body: Ellis Island scenes in the film highlight Vito Corleone's arrival to America, marking the beginning of his immigrant journey. This location frames the immigrant struggle that ultimately leads to the rise of the Corleone crime family, providing essential backstory and emotional grounding.

content.title: Symbolism
content.body: Ellis Island represents both opportunity and the harsh reality of adaptation and survival in a new country – themes that resonate deeply with the Corleone family’s narrative of assimilation, ambition, and the pursuit of power.

properties.role_in_film: Vito Corleone’s entry point to America
